Superintendent's Message on Fall Sports & Homecoming 2020

Families, Students and Stakeholders,

Keeping our students safe and healthy is our top priority here at TSD. As you may be aware, due to COVID-19 we will not be having any sports this fall season. Currently, it is too risky to have our students travel to other schools and sometimes other states to play sports. Since we will not be having football this season there will not be a homecoming celebration in the fall. We are currently monitoring the number of visitors who come on our campus and will not be able to host large groups here at the school at this time. Due to the ever-changing circumstances, in October we will make decisions about winter and spring sports and possibly have a homecoming during the winter sports season. Thank you for your patience.

Sincerely,
Vicki Kirk
Superintendent

In memory of William Edward "Ed" Davis
June 16, 1932 - July 1, 2020

Ed Davis was the Superintendent of Tennessee School for the Deaf, Knoxville for 22 years from 1973 - 1995. Prior to his role as Superintendent at TSD, he served as a Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor for the Deaf serving students at the school. He held two Masters degrees from the University of Tennessee in Music and Special Education/Deaf Education.

During his tenure as Superintendent, he established the preparatory program at the school for deaf students with additional disabilities, oversaw the construction of cottages transitioning the school from dorms to the residential life cottage program, and was also involved with establishing the West Tennessee School for the Deaf, and expanded statewide outreach services across the state.

TSD would like to express our condolences to Mr. Davis' family. Our thoughts are with you! We are grateful for his service.

TSD Iron Chef was held last week in the Old Gym SUB. Students' names were drawn and they were able to pick the staff they wanted to help them in the competition. Both teams were aware that the main ingredient would be steak, however, that night they were given two surprise ingredients that they had to use in the dish: Mango and Green Cabbage.

Once they were told the secret ingredients, they each had 3 minutes to deliberate what they were going to prepare for our 3 Dean judges. The dishes would be scored upon: creativity, presentation, and taste. Team 1 and 2 both cooked tacos, but the judges were very impressed by the creativity that Kevin Huff and his 2 student sous chefs displayed by infusing the steak with mango so they were gifted the Winner's Rolling Pin!

General John Alexander Cocke introduced legislation establishing Tennessee School for the Deaf that was passed by the House on January 29, 1844. Revered Thomas MacIntire who was a highly recommended teacher from what is now the Ohio School for the Deaf was selected to lead the school as principal and teacher. He opened the school on April 14, 1845 and the first students began class on the first Monday of June, 1845.

Senior class representatives were Shannon Murray, Sydney Rednour and Kylan Trice.

Congratulations and enjoy today's Homecoming!

The TSD Virtual Vikings team advanced to the semi-finals of the US Air Force Association’s CyberPatriot Competition. The students will compete (virtually) on Saturday, February 10 from 8 am until 3 pm in the technology classroom of the Alan J. Mealka High School. The students will work to find and resolve vulnerabilities in three different computer operating systems (Windows 10, Windows Server, and Ubuntu) while competing agains schools from all across the United States, Canada, US Territories, and military bases around the world. The team members are Haliey Robinson, Wilma Robinson, Kylan Trice, Jazzmyn Howard, and Tristen Webster. Coaches are Brandi Rood and Deetra Moore.

Go Virtual Vikings Team! Best wishes!!
